Posted: May 17, 2016
												Finally purchased Arma3 while it was reasonably priced and worth the real value of the game(s). The main problem is the game engine is POORLY optimized and HORRIBLE engine code. It's likely the engine for Arma3 had been rushed, it’s very clear the advances of mainstream computing were completely ignored. It’s like the developers were hiding under a rock.Even with a high end system, which is mostly used for rendering purposes within Professional applications [5960X, 128GB memory, 512 SSD, 4Titan], this game has trouble. I can run more demanding applications which ARE optimized without a hicup. Still Haswell-E are superior to Devil's Canyon and Skylake processors.With everything on ULTRA settings the game tends to jitter and textures do not fully load. So with some optimizations within the startup parameters the game ends up being quite pleasent. My tweaks:-window -high -nopause -skipintro -nosplash -useallavailablecores -cpucount=16 -maxmem=24576 -malloc=systemFor others, if you would like to use the above parameters the following tips for each parameter:1. The first five parameters are optionalALLOWS WINDOW MODE-window PLACES APPLICATION IN HIGH PRIORITY-highSETS THE GAME API TO ACTIVELY REFRESH IN THE BACKGROUND. It is especially useful for those using Athena or multiple displays. **** if this is not used, the game will seem frozen when it loses focus, meaning if you alt-tab to another application.-nopauseSKIPS STARTUP INTRODUCTION SCENES / MOVIES-skipintroSKIPS SPLASH SCREEN WHILE LOADING THE GAME, but not the addons splash-nosplash2. The last parameters tell the application to ignore the default ARMA engine settings set by BI developers.USES ALL CORES, BI has the application set as AUTO... but AUTO does not work and continues to use ONE core. BI DEVS have known of this issue since ARMA first released and for over a decade has not been resolved.-useallavailablecoresNEARLY THE SAME AS ABOVE, but informing the application HOW many cores your processor has. [red]**REMOVE THE ** AND TEXT WHEN ENTERING YOUR SETTINGS** [/red]-cpucount= **PHYSCIAL CORES+VIRTUAL CORES**ALLOWS THE APPLICATION TO USE A MAX DESIRED AMOUNT OF PHYSICAL MEMORY, though it doesn't literally use that, it's a reserve and the applicaiton may only see 1GB of memory rather than, in my case, 128GB of memory and NOT allocate memory correctly. [red]**REMOVE THE ** AND TEXT WHEN ENTERING YOUR SETTINGS**[/red]-maxmem= **ENTER at least 60-80% of your system memory**CUSTOM MEMORY ALLOCATOR *I prefer and suggest to others to use the SYSTEM string. There are others, but TBB4 and SYSTEM are the most mainstream and updated code. The reason this was added in the first place by BI develoeprs... is because ARMA is incapable of managing memory!!! LOL! Certainly tells you something about BI development.-malloc=systemThe main reason I would NOT recommend this game is because you have to search for the optimizations yourself. BI, developer, does NOT actively provide you the information upon installing the game and forces you THE PAYING CUSTOMER to use Bohemia Interactive developers brain-cell-lacking-mind DEFAULT applicaiton settings. I can name several high end simulation online games on the market that provide such options prior to launching the game. It's a simple GUI requesting CPU, GPU info and preferences. In any sense, if these developers had any, these options (among others) would be presented PRE- launching the application, that means every single application tweak that is KNOWN and UNKNOWN with a thorough explaination to each setting and string. Developers expect customers to purchase faulty and buggy software at exuberant prices yet they cannot fathom HOW to develop an application or provide functional and necessary settings for their customers. Though, not that alone, customers have to spend hours to adjust the game and search for the information. It’s a game… not a research paper for a doctoral thesis! If this is the case then Bohemia Interactive among other developers can start paying their customers for setting up the application on their system.In conclusion, these developers need to get their heads out of the sand!

content:
Posted: February 13, 2014
												ArmA III, the fourth game in the ArmA series, if we include the original Operation Flashpoint as well. Many mainstream 'FPS gamers' complain about ArmA's style, because it's unique? That's exactly why I love this game. You really have to find patience and a learning curve to this game. But once you have control over the game, you'll find tons of enjoyable content. You'll find yourself playing around with the editor, campaign with great storyline, 2 beautiful islands to explore, customizable gear, multiplayer fun as well as serious gameplay. What else do you want? Yeah it might have some bugs and lag. But, if you look back at ArmA 2, not many complained about it though ArmA 3 is highly improved from the previous title. ArmA is a huge game that you will be playing for years to come. You'll always find ways to emerge into ArmA's gameplay. It's ultimately up to you to be creative. Because of Bohemia Interactive's hard work on unique warfare gameplay, and immersive experience, I'd give it 9/10 :)

												Cannot and will not stop playing. Logged over 850 hours and still going strong. number of helpful: 10 of 13 people (77%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 18, 2015
												I definitly recommend this game. Why? No matter what kind of game you want to play, you find it in ArmA3. If you want an authentic tactical expierence, download some mods like ACE/ACRE and join a realism unit. More intrested in survival? Then hop on a wasteland or dayz server. Team Deathmatch? Then battleroyale is for you. Even if you like roleplay (altis life) or sector control (king of the hill) you will find what you are looking for.Graphics: 17/20, the game looks great overral, with beautiful landscapes, lightning and weather.Sound: 7/10, nothing too fancy here, but nothing bad either. If you want great sounds, then just download a mod.Storyline: 10/15, way better campaign than ArmA2, but let's be honest, there are better campaigns around. Don't play this game if you intend to only play it singleplayer, then you will be dissapointed.Gameplay: 28/30, absolutly great. The diversity of guns and vehicles in the main game is already great, and there are tons of mods around to get more weapons and vehicles. The scenario editor allows you to create simple and fun scenarios in a matter of seconds, and more advanced scenarios if you have the scripting expierence. Optimization: 12/15, lot's of people complain about this, which is something I don't understand. You don't need the best PC in the world to run this game on high settings, and you can adjust every setting in the game, allowing you to get the best perfomerance possible. For me, it runs fine on very high-ultra settings on a i3-3240 3.4GhZ duo core and a GTX 750ti with 40fps in multiplayer.Controls: 6/10, there is a great amount of controls to learn, which means there is quite a big learning curve for them. Aside from that, the default interaction menu is pretty horrible and glitchy, but then again, there are mods to fix this.Overal: 80/100. Just buy this game, I have enjoyed over 400 hunderd hours in this game, and still counting.

Posted: April 29, 2016
												I've noticed a lot of improvement graphically and mechanically in the Arma 3. However, the campaign is very boring and dull, which is really to be expected for a war simulator like Arma. When playing scenarios I've been trapped from house to house. One time I was cornered in a tiny house because there were 10 guys surrounding the compound. I somehow managed to kill like 5 of them before being shot. I quickly ran out and I was lucky to take cover. Most times in Arma, you can't do that. Which is interesting. Also, one time I got into an suv and I was supposed to kill this one guy in this crowd, so I crashed my car into the crowd and needless to say a bunch of people died. However, I was quickly killed because it's not like gta. The bullets go right through the car and shot me. There are glitches and it can be really boring at times. But experiences like these make it worth wild to buy. I encourage you to experiment with this game. 9.5/10

number of helpful: 6 of 6 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 26, 2014
												I've had this game since the first day of Alpha, and I can confidentally say that nothing comes close to Arma 3 in potential except maybe Arma 2 and minecraft. It's a fantastic sandbox military simulator where you can do anything you could imagine, no matter how dumb. It's a game where content is developed by the community, for the community. There are no set game modes or official servers, there aren' even any official game modes you can even download on their website. It's a completely player created game. Feel like invading either the islands of Altis and Stratis one minute and then role-playing as a drug dealer the next? Sure, why not. It's completely possible in Arma 3.Pros:• Almost limitless potential.• Close to an unlimited number of gamemodes created by the community.• Hundreds of community made campaigns and mods both avaliable on the workshop and on Armaholic (the go-to place for Arma mods).• Massive maps with none of those dumb loading screens every other game with maps on these scales seem to have. (Stratis is ~15-20km2, Altis is 270km2).• Large maps load very well and are very stable.• The ability to have infantry, armor, naval, and air battles at the exact same time on a much larger scale than you could imagine in another game such as Battlefield.• A wide variety of weapons, vehicles, and clothing.Cons:• Vehicles tend to explode a bit easier than they should.• Possibility of desync occuring on servers if they are overloaded.• Hit markers and boxes can be a bit buggy and glitchy.• Possibility of some pretty big lag. (Adding too many items/vehicles/AI/players to the game's already massive maps).As you can see, the pros easily outweight the cons. This game is fantastic. Even if you don't want to pay the full price for it, it goes on sale often enough and I promise, you won't regret it.9/10.

content:
Posted: July 28, 2015
												I have been with the serie since the first Arma and played countless of hours with A1, A2 absolutely loving the experience. My main interest in Arma games was always the mil sim part (not interested in any rpg/zombie modes) and so far A2 OA is the best for that. Sadly Bohemia got creative and put the A3 in the near future, with more futuristic forces what pretty much killed the "realistic mil sim" part for me.But still A3 is a great game. It's unbelievably moddable so I was able to get my modern military fix quickly with user created units.So, the good:-upgraded graphics engine-gigantic map-bipods! Yea, after few years they put bipods in game!-shooting from vehicles - same as with bipods - finally!-new more smooth and natural animations-game is super moddable-as usual great mission editor (I pretty much spent all my time creating my own missions).-driving is way more enjoyable than in any prev ArmasNow the bad:-no female soldiers/civilians -(if COD could we can too)-insane gun swaying and bobbing, gets infuriating-stamina - your soldier will fall on his face after running for 10 seconds-compare to A2 not that many various units-still no tank/apc interiors-lots of people reporting insane lag/fps issues MP and SP.Its a great game, and you can pretty much mod it to whatever you want - rpg/zombies/survival (blah...booring)/ military ops/racing- peek your fix.Still, if you are looking only for realistic military sim - get Arma 2 Operation Arrowhead and put the ACE mod into it - it will be insanely good and sadly better experience than A3.Great game, sadly not the best in the Arma franchise.

number of helpful: 7 of 8 people (88%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 25, 2016
												The enormity of the map is the foundation for the experiences that distinguish Bohemia Interactive's flagship franchise. It's what makes radios, topographical maps, binoculars, and compasses practical equipment in an FPS. It's what allows for kilometer-long headshots and coordinated convoy raids. It's what makes using your eyes to spot hints of enemies--muzzle flashes, tracers, gunsmoke--as valuable as being a crack shot. Arma 3 represents an aesthetic overhaul of the series. Unbelievable dynamic lighting, a volumetric cloud system, genuine vehicle physics, 3D weapon optics, ragdoll, noticeably improved weapon audio, and other grainy, eye-level details await scrutiny inside Arma 3's macro elegance. The best improvement is the merciful cutting of Arma 2's rigid, Tin-Man-without-oil combat animations, which makes infantry combat more responsive in your hands. With voice-connected friends and a good user-created mission, Arma 3 is an unparalleled war story generator. On Operation Fault Line with a gang of Steam pals, I had to drive a clumsy, eight-wheeled transport called a HEMTT across the map. To protect this elephantine truck we had a IFV-6c Panther, an APC with a mounted grenade launcher and 12.7mm MG. Minutes after leaving base, our tanky bodyguard eats a land mine, ruining its left track. As we get out to survey the damage, rockets streak across the valley. Everyone's okay, but the Panther is immobilized.

number of helpful: 28 of 48 people (58%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 30, 2015
												I tried to enjoy this game, but I could not. I have several aspects I'd like to point out to make clear why I don't recommend buying this game:1 - A totally unoptimized engine The graphics in this game are great, no doubt about that. But the engine and the FPS I am getting definetely are not. My PC has up-to-date-components which do meet the recommend requirements, except for my graphics card. It is a GTX 760, recommended one is a GTX 680 though. I accept that I cant get the best amount of FPS with this card in a a game like Arma 3 - but only 27 FPS Max in a multiplayer match with ~ 10 people online and the graphics settings at low, view distance set to 1000 and with shadows deactivated? This is not a fault of my 760, it is because the engine of this game is totally unoptimized. 2 - An AI which is dumb as f***I expect, that the AI in a game that is based so heavily on teamwork is atleast ACCEPTABLE. But this is not the case in Arma 3, no! The AI of the comrades you will lead during several singleplayer missions is so bad, that I would need to look for a word to describe it. They resist to follow your orders instantly, for example when you tell them to enter a car. They will walk around like a headless chicken before finally remembering that there is a car they should enter. And if you're unlucky, they won't enter the car at all. This is just one exmaple, but there are many cases where the AI would have to be improved. Maybe in Arma 4, which I certainly won't buy if they keep their attitude towards the game and the players like in Arma 3.3 - Terrible mission designThere are several missions which do just have terrible design. For example a mission where you have to make your way through a destroyed town with tons of enemies, vehicles (which I couldn't use for some reason) and barely any supplies. But this is not the only case. There are several other missions with a bad design, where you maybe have to walk for several minutes, or run to keep up with your mate and then encounter an enemy squad but you can't hit any of them because your level of fatigue is too high so that your hands shake and can't aim as you would need too. Sure, it might be realistic, but here it is just GAMEBREAKING. Luckily there is a way to skip a mission: Hold down Shift and - on your numpad and then type "endmission" (you can release Shift and - while typing). And I am thankful for this option because I was stuck forever with this one particular mission, but let's move on.4 - (Small) Things that could have been betterThere are some small things aside from the big ones that coould have been better if the developers would have taken more time to improve the game. For example the body armor in the singleplayer. Depending on what pieces of armor you're wearing, you get an armor rating (which you can't see anywhere), and the amount of shots you can tolerate before dying depends on that rating. Sometimes I would just die from one shot (and no, it wasn't the .408 CT or the 99x108mm (.50) that hit me) and wonder why I died although I was wearing armor (note that I am talking of the singleplayer) and the enemy did take like 4 shots to kill! Seems like my armor rating was not high enough. But how should I know? See, the problem is that you can't know, because nowhere is written how good that armor is. It would've been nice if they would have given every piece of armor a value, like "0" for no protection, "40"-"70" for decent protection and "100" for high protection.They should have also provided checkpoints for campaign levels. Well, you can save manually, bu if you forgot to and die, well you will be kinda annoyed when you have to do the whole mission again and let me tell you that the missions are not short ones. But  there are also  good things about the game. The graphics are beautiful and if you have a high amount of FPS I'm sure that the multiplayer provides alot of fun. Thee are also so many vehicles from tanks to submarines, artillery,  jets, choppers, attack boats...  There is also an option to make time passing by faster. Press the key to the left of "Backspace" to increase time's speed, and the button left to this one to decrease time's speed. Especially useful when you have to  walk forever again.And another aspect I like are the realistic ballistics of the guns depending on their ammunition type. "But CaVe_DoVah, you wrote that u don't like it when u die from one shot. Seems like u have no idea and are not trustworthy!" No, wait. I wrote that I did not like the system with the armor rating. But the ballistics should stay like they are, because what would a military simulator be without realistic ballistics?I think that everyone should decide on their own whether they buy this game or not. I just tried to help you (and hope I succeeded) with this choice by writing about the negative aspects, since there are enough reviews already which cover the good ones enough. I personally regret to have bought this game, mostly because of the FPS I am getting although I am close to the recomended requirements, but hey, that's just my opinion.

number of helpful: 10 of 14 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 28, 2014
												I picked this game up when it first came out and have spent tons of time playing it since then.  As with all the previous Arma series it has its problems (most of which I believe, should have been fixed before being sold to the public), but even with its faults it is still the closest thing to a real infantry simulator that a non-military person can purchase.With mods the game gets even better and more playable, and less 'sci-fi' like.  Also, I've never played any of the single player stuff that comes with the game, I only do multiplayer with my group and I really enjoy it.Things to watch out for;  you need a fast processor for this game - DO NOT buy it if your CPU isn't over 3.5 M.  All of the Arma games are CPU intensive and this one is the worst for it.Don't expect it to be easy - this isn't Call of Duty or some other 'fps' that has the AI standing around waiting for you.  They'll hide, shoot at distance and even chase you around.  Use real-world tactics, if you're with friends, and see how well they work (they do), think 'stay alert' and you'll survive longer.There's loads of stuff I could say about this game, but really I play it for about 20 hours or so a week and really enjoy it.

content:
Posted: June 17, 2014
												This game offers a lot. And I mean A LOT. You can download endless missions made from the community workshop and play with strategy with your friends or run around half naked and dance around. Or you could roleplay and buy an ATM from all the drug money you earned in Altis Life. Or have races with friends in Karts. This game is an Army Simulator, but it's great for modding which let's you do more things.Now, this game isn't something like COD or Battlefield, it takes strategy and tactics and patience. If you come from these games it will be harder to get into fast. Although if you play through the campaign it will help you get used to the game. Please don't think the warfare in this game is just pew pew pew, die, respawn, repeat. It takes skill.Altis is a very big map, you can drive around for what seems like forever in this beautiful map. There is forestry, a lot of ocean, desert, grassland, etc. There is also Stratis, a smaller, more wastelandish and deserty than Altis. You need a good PC to run this game. I usually get around 45 fps on online servers, around 60 on single player or games with small amounts of people in it.Overall, this game has a ton of things to do and you can't get bored of it. I give it a 9.5/10

number of helpful: 11 of 16 people (69%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 13, 2014
												Probably the closest thing that us, the general population, has towards a realistic military simulator/game.I suggest that you do not buy this if you are expecting a linear fast paced action game like CoD or Battlefield, this is much more in-depth then that. This is not simply, running around 360 no scoping people. Squad Managment and effective communication is necessary. There is also something that you can't experience in the said titles above, which is long-range combat. (An example of this is preforming an assault on a base/camp with armor, artillery and other assests from varying distances from your own base.However, this is still a game and should be taken lightly from time to time. I suggest learning how to do tricks in the littlebird (MH9-Hummingbird) and exploiting the terrible physics. This game has multiple different gamemodes and tasks that could be simulated. So you'll never have the same experience twice.Pros:-Very Realistic.-Great Graphics (If you can run them).-Interactive Environment.-Realisitc Vehicals (Most of the time).------------------------------------------------------------------------Cons:-Physics (You will hear "Arma Physics" referred to multiple times).-Muliplayer Optimization.-Very steep learning curve but you will appreciate it over time. (More of a learn as you play)-Occasional Crashing.-Controls will more than likely conflict your normal keyboard setup, I suggest using the Arma 2 setup. Overall10/10Even if you don't think this is for you, trust me, the teamwork involved in this game is beyond amazing, the amount of co-op I've played counts for 95% of my game time. I've met tons of new people from this and they're like family to me.

Posted: May 8, 2015
												Early into the game, I noticed a few problems. The graphics are a little dated, but hold up overall. The big problem I see, is with the constant fadeout to FMV. This seems to occur so frequently throughout the Prologue, I began wondering what the point of the game actually was. I get it, that this was a tutorial phase; However, I could do with less fadeaway's and more actual gameplay. With the Con's out of the way, I like the realistic feel to the game, from the weaponry and equipment, to the military jargon, it has an air of authenticity, which makes these types of games appealing to many. Arma 3, may have it's flaws, but overall it isn't a bad game. If I were in charge, I would have modernized the graphics a bit, and put a greater emphasis on the smaller details such as battlefield damage to structures and the environment, the movement of the weeds, grass and tree's in the wind, and other little things to enhance the immersion experience. Still a recommendable game for those interested in Army Warfare Sims.

content:
Posted: May 12, 2015
												I gave this a shot over the free weekend and here's what I learned: 1. You need an incredibly modern and powerful gaming PC to run attractive graphics with this. My system is 5 years old,  570 GTX can barely run this at the lowest graphics settings possible, and that's barely getting 30 fps.  2. The amount of key mapping you need to do to make this even somewhat manageable as a "game" is insane. Basically, you need one of those 7 or 9 button gaming Mice, because you won't have enough sensible keyboard key locations to cover all of the crap. 3. For a game where voice communication is extremely necessary, the voice comm functionality in this game is quite limited, but that's not really an issue because everyone is going to be using TS3 anyway... 4. Good luck finding a decent server to play on. Most of them are run by fascist bronys. Others are run by incompetent admins and you can count on getting spawnkilled by your own team over and over until you leave and find a different server.  No, I'm not kidding.  5. The game isn't worth 60 dollars.  The rest of the game (that's right, you don't actually get the whole game for 60 dollars, you need all of the DLC too because the only good weapons are locked)  is going to run you even more.  So it's over $100 game that isn't worth playing unless you have a $2,500 computer and a $120 mouse. 6. It seems like, if you met all of the requirements above,  the game *could* be enjoyable.  Just know what you are really getting yourself into...

content:
Posted: December 4, 2014
												Adolf Hitler (German: [ˈadɔlf ˈhɪtlɐ]; 20 April 1889 – 30 April 1945) was an Austrian-born German politician and the leader of the Nazi Party (German: Nationalsozialistische Deutsche Arbeiterpartei (NSDAP); National Socialist German Workers Party). He was chancellor of Germany from 1933 to 1945 and dictator of Nazi Germany (as Führer und Reichskanzler) from 1934 to 1945. Hitler was at the centre of Nazi Germany, World War II in Europe, and the Holocaust.Hitler was a decorated veteran of World War I. He joined the German Workers' Party (precursor of the NSDAP) in 1919, and became leader of the NSDAP in 1921. In 1923, he attempted a coup in Munich to seize power. The failed coup resulted in Hitler's imprisonment, during which time he wrote his memoir, Mein Kampf (My Struggle). After his release in 1924, Hitler gained popular support by attacking the Treaty of Versailles and promoting Pan-Germanism, antisemitism, and anti-communism with charismatic oratory and Nazi propaganda. Hitler frequently denounced international capitalism and communism as being part of a Jewish conspiracy.Hitler's Nazi Party became the largest elected party in the German Reichstag, leading to his appointment as chancellor in 1933. Following fresh elections won by his coalition, the Reichstag passed the Enabling Act, which began the process of transforming the Weimar Republic into the Third Reich, a single-party dictatorship based on the totalitarian and autocratic ideology of National Socialism. Hitler aimed to eliminate Jews from Germany and establish a New Order to counter what he saw as the injustice of the post-World War I international order dominated by Britain and France. His first six years in power resulted in rapid economic recovery from the Great Depression, the denunciation of restrictions imposed on Germany after World War I, and the annexation of territories that were home to millions of ethnic Germans, actions which gave him significant popular support.Hitler actively sought Lebensraum ("living space") for the German people. His aggressive foreign policy is considered to be the primary cause of the outbreak of World War II in Europe. He directed large-scale rearmament and on 1 September 1939 invaded Poland, resulting in British and French declarations of war on Germany. In June 1941, Hitler ordered an invasion of the Soviet Union. By the end of 1941 German forces and their European allies occupied most of Europe and North Africa. Failure to defeat the Soviets and the entry of the United States into the war forced Germany onto the defensive and it suffered a series of escalating defeats. In the final days of the war, during the Battle of Berlin in 1945, Hitler married his long-time lover, Eva Braun. On 30 April 1945, less than two days later, the two committed suicide to avoid capture by the Red Army, and their corpses were burned. Under Hitler's leadership and racially motivated ideology, the regime was responsible for the genocide of at least 5.5 million Jews, and millions of other victims whom he and his followers deemed racially inferior.

Wow, such invention, great detail.* Mods for everything. Mods, mods, mods, mods. Can't find your vehicle? Add it with a mod. Can't find the mod? Create the mod.* A totally split up community of players with an unknown ratio of butthurt fans in denial and realists that has been betrayed by their favorite studio.* Refunds? Nope.While waiting for Arma 3 to be released as a full product, you can also wait for BIS's other projects:* DayZ 2* Take on Mars* VBS* Arma TacticsAnd to top it all off, when I made a thread to complain about all these promised things that they never put in the game on their official forum, they edited it heavily and left me looking like a fool:http://forums.bistudio.com/showthread.php?167844-Thanks-to-Bohemia-Interactive-StudioOriginal post:https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/28058839/BIS%20Forum%20Thread.txtThey obviously know that they lack content but they aren't really good at damage control. Here's their €500'000 competition of who can make content to Arma 3:http://makearmanotwar.com/ Twitter: #MakeArmaExpect this game to be fully loaded with content sometime at Q4 of 2014. If you have the patience to download all the mods through PlayWithSix.Thanks for the 8 fedoras ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s.

number of helpful: 14 of 22 people (64%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 12, 2016
												I hope that one day ArmA will use more than 30% of PC resources and actually play well.The optimisation is horrid, the game won't use more than like a third of your resources, leading to horrible stuttering gameplay, can't utilise a good view distance etc.I have an i5 6600k overclocked, and a GTX 1070 overclocked with 16GB RAM, a very capable and pretty well high end computer in terms of performance, and average in terms of it's what most people will buy..With all the optimising and tuning down of some settings and a very minimal view distance, I still only average 40FPS with stuttering, sometimes a little higher, sometimes dropping down to FPS in the 20's inside planes.Can't help but feel I'd be getting close to 90+ FPS with settings turned up if the game would take full advantage of the system and use all of the resources..It's performance is simply just not the best it can be, and I hope they take the opportunity to revamp the engine for ArmA 4, or implement a revamped, better performing engine into the game we have.That's the bad, and unfortunately I have to put "Don't recomment this game" for anyone to take note of this, the performance is the only bad thing about this game.In terms of fun, it's the best thing in my library. Online server and mod support is amazing, best of any game I've played. Insert the mod into the game's root folder and load it up through the launcher, how amazing and simple is that? No game breaking tinkering involved, plug 'n' play pretty much.Gameplay minus performance is hectic, CoD and Battlefield ain't got nothing on ArmA. For the first time realism is fun, they pretty much nailed it. AI can be a little silly, but good for our time, and expected from un-scripted AI's in today's games.DLC (At least, Apex) was a little pricey, don't get me wrong, Apex is good, but not nearly original game's price good.Great game, my main and only beef with it is the performance, and that's why it gets the red thumb. When they fix performance I'll edit my review.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2014
★★★★★★★★★★10/10Most incredible military simulation game I have ever played. Amazing graphics, true realism, believable ballistics on weapons, open world sandbox, large extensive battlefields and maps.A bit futuristic in terms of technology of the equipment (classic example is the numerous drone UAV models and types), which might not suit players who do not like modern weaponry and tactics.Other than that the game includes all, or most of the requested features for the previous versions and as a result presents a general advancement in the series (congratulations to the developers).I am satisfied with this game and I enjoy playing it, both multiplayer and single-player. - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -"This is Lieutenant Cole, reporting target area has been secu--""Woah, get down!""This is two-five, we've got several technicals in the streets, taking heavy fire - requesting permission to withdraw to the mansion - out! --""Zero-niner here, sit tight two-five, we have dispatched a helicopter squad for support, they're on their way to assist - ETA 17 minutes - I say again, sit tight, help is on its way - over.""Zero-niner, we cannot hold this navpoint anymore - we need to pull back from this position, if we keep this up we're going to have too many damn wounded to move! We need to exfiltrate to the mansion!"(brief silence)"They've brought armor zero-niner, THEY'VE BROUGHT ARMOR - TAKING HEAVY FIRE - WE'RE WITHDRAWING TO NEAREST CHECKPOI--"*radio static*"Two-five - come in, two-five? What the hell happend out there? Come in -  give me a sitrep - come in, two-five, over!"To be continued...

content:
Posted: June 10, 2015
I might be biased, but this is worth the money 100%.The DLC, the community made mods and scenarios, the game itself, it’s all at the top of the pile when it comes to being a game spanning the entire military simulator genre. I have 700 hours in the game and I  KNOW  that it’s only the tip of the iceberg. The quality of some of the mods released for this game (all free, by the way) are worth the price of the game alone. Then comes the DLC from Bohemia, Free to access to all players, only difference by paying is almost entirely cosmetic bonuses. This is a great game, single player or multiplayer, it’s all good. If you like being immersed into an incredibly large and diverse world where split-second decisions matter, you will LOVE this title. Be warned though, if you are used to fast pace action shooters, this is not one of them.

content:
Posted: April 22, 2016
												There is a Soviet joke from early 80s that goes like this:Moscow, summer morning, Sheremetyevo airport.A representative of some very successful Japanese tech corporation heads back to his homeland after an official visit to USSR during which he observed the technological feats of Soviet people. Of course, a huge delegation of Party leaders and reporters is present, just like during any other event of this sort. So, as he walks to his plane, he becomes surrounded by reporters and they ask him, "What have you liked the most about Soviet Union?".— You have great children, they're so playful, happy and optimistic about their future.— Awesome! - reporters reply - and have you liked anything else?— You have great children.— Yeah, we love our children too, but what about our cars and TVs and fridges and roads and other things?— You have great children - the representative replies - but everything you make with your hands is terribly bad.So, Arma series has a really great community. An amazing one, really. I'm thoroughly convinced that no other game has a similar one. But everything made by Bohemia Interactive...Well, it's not exactly terribly bad (and at times it's quite good actually) but Arma, in a way, carries the spirit of Soviet Union's industry: a single manufacturer that gets most of its revenue from excellent military products also produces various civilian goods. These goods, however, while being suitable for their purpose, have a mediocre quality, especially compared to the products of Western companies. But it's the only manufacturer in the country and the Iron Curtain is still in place so you don't really have a choice but to recommend these products to your family and friends.You really like that Mercedes-Benz W123? Well, too bad, here's a ticket for UAZ-496, comrade.You're #47,254,875 in the queue.

number of helpful: 6 of 7 people (86%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 21, 2013
												One of the best military games available.Its sandbox style and modding/customizations allow it to become almost anything you want.Co-operative military simulator, role-playing game, survival horror, you name it.It offers so many possibilities it has an endless replay value.What this game is to me is a military simulator, it has a numerous amount of upgrades from the previous Arma 2/Op. Arrowhead, most importantly the infantry handling and animations that now offer much more flexibility and greater control over your character.Vehicles none the less have been upgraded, the new PhysX 4 engine gives vehicles a much more realistic feeling.Lights and scenario rendering have been not only upgraded, but made even LIGHTER for your pc to run, as opposed to the incredibly heavy Arma 2 engine that would put an incredible amount of stress even to the most high-end gaming rigs.The downside however is that as of now the game doesn't offer much sandbox content as in vehicles and weapons but the developers have already announced future free DLCs that would address this and add some other cool features.In conclusion i think this game offers infinite possibilities to those who can take advantage of them but it still needs some time to grow and reach its full potential, what we'll have then will be a game that is going to put to shame all the other commercial FPSs.

number of helpful: 6 of 7 people (86%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 2, 2016
												Arma is a great game in a few ways and a terrible game in a lot of ways. If you're looking for something realistic this is it, well kind of. It's very deep and goes a long way to try and be realistic. In most ways it succeeds. In a few though it doesn't, the biggest example of this being the inclusion of 3rd person. 3rd person ruins it for me because players can peak around corners and over ledges with no penalty or chance of being seen while doing so. There's a ton of content, a large community (most of which are ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s but that's usual and shouldn't matter in a review imo), and a lot of thought still goes into this game. The bulk of your experience will be online multiplayer most likely. Possibly just messing around in the 3d editor though. The controls are vast and take a lot of getting used to. The movement is clunky as hell, the environments are ugly as hell (the jungle looks nice in trailers but there's only like 4 different tree assets that just repeat all over the place so after a few minutes you've seen it all) and that's extra $$$$. If you're going to get this because of FrankyPC's vids - don't. Those are scripted and this game is 80% running / driving and then some really clunky fights. I still recommend this game with those downfalls because it's still a ton of fun if you give it time to grow on you.

number of helpful: 6 of 7 people (86%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 23, 2015
												ARMA 3 definitely brought a lot of improvements from the previous installment of the series, the visual element is the best example, if you have a good enough computer, you can admire the beautiful scenery of Altis & Stratis.The map is even bigger than before, the single player campaign is interesting enough, it keep me entertained although it was difficult until i learned the controls and the stamina conditioning.The cons are still the same for me, too many controls to learn and master as i believe that the game would benefit from way simpler controls and the confusing + somewhat buggy squad of bots that you must control on the single player mode.I know this doesnt bother the multiplayer aspect, but it did bother on the campaign as they didnt obey certains which all more difficult.But i most certainly recommend ARMA 3 because its a great military simulation for those interested in such and it also can be whatever you want, just download the mod that suits you best.7/10

												Recommending this game is a no-brainer. If you are even marginally into shooters with a nag for realism Arma 3 is inevitable. The game won't let you in easily; it has a steep learning curve, and starting out can be quite frustrating. Also, you are less likely to find good public servers; it hardly is hop-on and play like CoD or Battlefield. The best way to experience it is in a clan or community group. Bottom line, go get it. number of helpful: 7 of 9 people (78%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2013
												ARMA 3 is a game in a class of its own and defines the genre of tactical military simulations. One of the greatest benefits is the modability and vast amount of user created content, that can be implemented in this very open sandbox. The first part of the campaign "Survive" showed that Bohemia Interactive made their game also interesting for singleplayer, but the true strength of ARMA 3 is for sure the multiplayer.Don't get me wrong - this game needs a certain level of dedication to get the maximum out of it, casual players probably won't get happy. If you want a unique mod- and mission-setting you cannot just create a game and simply "hop in". Hosting a MP-server with mods, creating MP-missions that work flawless with mods - all of this stuff can be quite complex and hard to be learned by one person alone. But if you decide to join a group or community that suites your style of play (action-, hardcore-simulation-, roleplay-orientated or somewhere in between) then you might get a most interesting and challenging game experience.

number of helpful: 8 of 11 people (73%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 30, 2014
												After building on their signature game engine Bohemia has truly put forward a simulation gem with Arma 3 that no other game franchise has even come close to matching.  This is where you hit the dirt, and find that bullets aren't all warning shots, and that the blood on your face can't be waited out, but that bullets will kill you, and that you'll have to wipe that blood off yourself.While it still isn't the most stable engine a game has run on, it's the most advanced one I know of, with all the trimmings of environment that effect the battle and without all the crashes of Battlefield 4.  Bohemia has brought the Arma series to it's highest point ever, and it's playability has been increased 200%.  I can't reccomend this game to everyone, but there's one great lesson learned in my time with Arma;I've ended missions in other games seemingly covered in blood, wearing a bandana and sporting no shirt but instead a big sculpted chest and a BFG in each hand... And yet, I'd rather I could just make it home with a mission well done and all of my team safe and sound...This is what Arma is...It's fighting a real fight, where you have to pace yourself and hold your breath, where a bullet in the face can kill a man regardless of whether he's controlled by a player or an AI.  It's using your map, intel and wits to determine the best angle of attack on an enemy position, and sighing in relief when you find out later that you picked a good entry point.It's being truly tense, when you lie hiding in the bushes, hoping the MRAP with a GMG turret didn't spot you when it's lights passed over you, and hoping that you can get everyone home safe at the end of the day.Hundreds of hours into this game, I have yet to be bored even on the most patiently conducted sniper missions.  There's a satisfying reward in every mission in this game, and maybe that's because you really have to work to make it out alive.  Seriously, put on your boots because as far as a game goes, this is as close as it gets.  This is Arma, and there is nothing else like it.~Valtros

												This is the definitive military experience, sure it might be rough around the edges and maybe it can be a bit unforgiving at times, but no other military shooter out there comes even close to what ARMA 3 offers, unlimited replayability, thousands of campaigns and scenarios, mods, coop, vehicles, exploration, and above all a sense of total inmersion.With the upcoming free dlc, and a huge community behind it, Bohemia interactive have again struck gold, having played their games since Operation Flashpoint, it has been an awesome surprise to see how far they have taken the genre forward, although, be advised, Call of Warfare fans will be in for a shock as nothing they have learnt there will have much use in here!The graphics are amazing, the movement and controls are the best in the series, but be advised, you will have to take time to learn the ins and outs of the game, as it is sometimes unforgiving of even the slightest mistakes, eventually you get the hang of it and this game really shines!Must buy!Get your gun soldier and hit the dirt!

number of helpful: 9 of 13 people (69%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 20, 2014
												At first I was very skeptical about Arma III. Playing Arma II was not such a pleasant experience, and I was very happy that I haven't wasted my money on this when the Day Z mod came out, So I bought Arma III expecting something as bad as the previous Arma. But I was surprised. The graphics, movement, squad management, driving and many other features were massively improved. I`m not even talking about shooting. Recoil and gun damage is so realistic. But the inventory system probably is the most improved thing since Arma II. Now you can easily see whats on the ground, or in the vehicle, or simply add attachments for your gun ( which  are awesome! ). There`s no more arrow clicking and usual inventory lag. The only things that needs fixing are glitches and AI. Glitches should be fixed in future patches, but the AI need some work done. The AI could be both very easy to take down and extremely punishing at the same time. Sometimes AI just stands there for couple of seconds and then starts shooting, or instantly spots you and shoots you down in a few shots. I think Bohemia Interactive should really focus on this problem, because its not so serious as it is irritating, All in all, if you want some new experience of shooting game that requests some planing, patience and cooperation instead of "being your own little Rambo", you definitely should check out Arma III.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2015
												WIth the latest awful patch, it is usually impossible to connect in hosted MP. 1/3 of missions that we actually get playing soon drop to 1 FPS, requiring a restart. The devs ignore these issues.Other issues:Spyware!Endless bugsNew bugs every patchTerrible performanceThe developers don't care about the gameConstantly drops to 1 FPS (devs refuse to address this)Latest patch randomly kicks/prevents joining servers (devs refuse to address this)Broken AIBroken features100% reliant on 3rd party mods for bugfixes, playability and contentArma 2 offers more for lessI have over 2000 hours in Arma 3 alone, more in the other entries in the series. I have been modding and making missions since the early 2000s. I am the guy who introduced dynamic missions and campaigns to the series. That said, Arma 3 is not worth your money.Arma 3 is basically a patch of OFP, a game that came out in 2001. The graphics are better, there are new scripting commands and the inventory system is better, but those are the only real improvements. In recent patches BIS finally implemented weapon resting (something modders had in Arma 2 years ago), but it is clumsy and poorly-implemented. The modded solutions are vastly superior.Every patch for Arma 3 is a disaster. What is broken this time? What features have stopped working? What mods are broken now? Will my performance get worse again?The latest patch has broken MP. My coop group can not join missions now, despite our modset being identical. Sometimes after trying to join over and over it will let players in. Then when we restart the mission it won't let people join. Last time we played it took over an hour of disabling mods and endless retries before we could play a single mission. It seems the devs are cracking down on mods.Even the bugs are broken. Often bugs happen randomly and in a non-reproducable way. Sometimes the AI driver won't follow movement orders, sometimes he will. There is no pattern.A big problem is that control of your AI squadmates is much worse than previous games. In OFP your could use tactical view to position your guys, tell them to hold fire and they would do it. This made it possible to set up ambushes. In Arma 3 this is impossible. Your AI will often not move to where you click on the map. A very common occurence is to order your squad to a position 100 meters behind you and they will instead move 100 meters in front.Friendly AI struggle to engage enemy targets. Countless times I have seen my troops blankly staring down their sights at an enemy for several seconds, finally getting shot instead. In contrast, the enemy can still do a first-shot head-shot over iron sights from 200 meters away, something people complained about in 2001.AI squadmates are little more than extra lives in coop. At least the needless respawn delay has finally been removed.Another bug is when your squad takes fire, they will enter combat mode and you can't get them out of it. They become unresponsive to commands and are out of your control. This makes it impossible to break contact or dash to a new position. In other words, when you take fire, you lose control of your squad. This can be fixed with mods, but not in vanilla. Again, modders save the day because the devs don't care.If you are a group commander in a vehicle but switch to gunner and then exit the vehicle, the vehicle driver will run over you. EVERY. SINGLE. TIME. It is things like this that make me think the devs never even play their game.That said, enemy AI is improved over OFP. However, the AI still requires mods do basic things like enter buildings, take cover, call for support, crew weapons etc.AI are even less capable of driving than previous games. I made a mission where the enemy starts in a village and spreads out from there, seizing the map town by town. However, I noticed that a few minutes after spawning, the enemy technical groups slowed down greatly. When I used a camera view to debug, I saw that most of the AI had crashed their vehicles so badly (whilst safe and driving down empty roads), that they had wrecked the vehicles in their group and were now on foot.Let that sink in. The AI can not drive down roads for a few kilometers without wrecking their vehicles, even when not in combat.The implementation of PhysX is terrible and often slows the game to a crawl or crashes it. About one in three coop games requires a restart because a vehicle gets stuck on a building and the FPS hits 4. You will also see hilarious glitches like tanks suddenly flying into the air for no reason.The worst thing about Arma 3 is that the developers just don't care. They ignore major bugs, but then implement rubbish that nobody wants. So now there is Workshop integration (who cares?), but you still can't control your troops in combat.Despite existing in earlier games, there are no females in Arma 3. So what do the devs give us? Go karts! It is absurd.The action menu was terrible when OFP was released in 2001, and Bohemia has made no efforts to improve it. For those not familiar with it, you have to use the middle mouse button to control essential actions. Say you want to climb a ladder, you might accidentally set off your satchel charges instead. Or a single mis-click and you turn off your helicopter's engine. There are several mods which show how this could be done better, but again, the devs don't care.A great point is the modding community. There are tons of fantastic mods that add units, islands, functions and fix Bohemia's shoddy work.People will tell you that Arma 3 is some super-realistic military simulation. It has realistic elements, but it also has magic medkits that instantly heal you. The tanks are STILL using a hitpoint system and can be killed with any weapon as long as you hit it enough times. Also, tanks still do stupid things like get into combat, inexplicably expose their rear armor to the enemy and then use their coax to engage an MRAP whilst ignoring some AFV that is shooting them.The artillery system is a joke. Some of the special round types (eg. guided shells) don't work at all.The naval aspect is a gimmick with zero value in the game. There are no true naval assets, the aquatic elements serve absolutely no purpose and are useless in game.In those rare cases when it all comes together, nothing breaks and you are fighting the enemy instead of the game engine, Arma 3 can offer an amazing experience like no other game. But you will need to spend dozens of hours researching and installing mods and learning how to avoid the bugs. Arma 3 is broken and unfinished, you will have to invest a lot of time to make it work for you. Vanilla offers a boring, unpolished, unfinished experience. Every patch will require more hours of troubleshooting before you can play smoothly again.If you really want to see what Arma has to offer, just get Arma 2 and its addons. It is much cheaper, has about 500% of the content of Arma 3, is more stable and has far more mods. In fact one of the major modding projects for Arma 3 is to import Arma 2 content. Arma 2 has far more islands and factions. You will not have to deal with all of the bugs Arma 3 introduces.Some fanboys will attack this review. But I have been contributing to OFP/Arma community for over a decade. I am sick of waiting for Bohemia to take their game seriously and fix the bugs. It seems all they care about now is Life game modes.I could go on and on. One final bug: the one where you suddenly start flapping your arms and floating in the air like a bird.Bottom line: Arma 3 is definitely not worth the money. Arma 2 can provide more than Arma 3 at a much lower cost and with less bugs. Even if you get Arma 3 for free, you will have to invest a lot of time and effort into it to make it playable. Even then, sometimes it will simply not let you join a server.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 26, 2014
												If Call of Duty is a Hollywood "military porn" movie, and Battlefield is the docudrama on military subjects, Arma is the trip down to the local military base, spending time on the range and on the obstacle course, and learning the real deal from the real people. Its about as close as you can get without signing up.Arma 3 is a sandbox infantry simulator with a focus on authenticity, set in a near-future ficticious scenario of 2035, wherein NATO is but a shadow of its former (aka: current-day) self, and a new enemy of Iranian origin begins a localized takeover of a small collection of islands in the Agean Sea, leading to a potential "flashpoint" of a wider war between NATO-allied nations near the Medittereanean and the Iranian-led "CSAT" forces, with Greek-based freedom fighters and the Greek army caught inbetween.There is a large focus (stemming from 4 games prior, not including expansions) on realism, and not the Hollywood "realism" that Call of Duty or Battlefield would throw at you. This game has proper modelling of terminal ballistics (range, ballistics drop, penetration, deflection, windage), proper modelling of the kilometers of distances you'll oftentimes have to travel, proper weapons, vehicles, and equipment modelling and mechanics, and proper tactics and strategy implementation.How proper? Well the seminal game of the series, let alone this infantry simulator genre, was the penultimate "Operation Flashpoint" of 2001 (now named Arma: Cold War Assault), which led to the development of the Virtual Battlespace 1 and 2 interactive training simulator aids that are currently being used by world militaries around the world, alongside the next games in the series (with the new name), Armed Assault (or Arma).Whilst there is a singleplayer campaign of due note (and one that is highly recommendable to newcomers to the series as the campaign since Arma 1 has always been structured to deliver a solid singleplayer experience at the same time introduce and teach the fundamental mechanics of the game), the real focus of the game is in its sandbox nature, allowing a very fanatic and vibrant community to create missions of all kinds, oftentimes with a multiplayer bent, for the game. Many of these missions are in the Steam Workshop, a first for the series.The multiplayer aspect of this game is extensive and ranges from straight-up "hardcore" simulation fanatics, exercising proper military procedures, tactics, and actions, to GTA-like -Life servers, Wasteland (read: DayZ in Arma), and everything in between (Insurgency, and Domination/Invade&Annex). In fact, many of the aformentioned gameplay types are all community-born, with the different communities that play Arma oftentimes having vastly different variants of each type, with many having a lot of bleed-over into each other, or being a singular experience on their own. One's multiplayer experiences are oftentimes directly tied to the quality of the people that share the same experience with you, and Arma's many communities are a notch above the expected grade, with all kinds from laid-back to straight-up, oftentimes with people who are former and even current serving military. You wont feel alone if you look around, and the people you will find are of all kinds, many for the better.This game is highly recommended to those who feel that Battlefield is not a solid enough experience and want to get deeper into the mindset of a soldier in a more authentic worldspace, and want to see how and why military tactics of today work they way they work, from close-quarters battle (CQB) in room clearing, to urban MOUT combat and open areas, to infantry - mechanized - armor - air interplay and supports.

content:
Posted: November 4, 2013
												ArmA III... Another timeless source of entertainment from Bohemia Interactive. Although it improves upon its predecessor - ArmA II / Operation Arrowehad - in many ways, there is definately room for improvement. While the game is more intensive on your hardware, especially CPU and GPU, for obvious reasons, the game does appear to be lacking a bit of optimisation. Saying that, it's not bad at all, and is perfectly playable. Players on a lower end PC may experience serious lag issues when playing large missions, especially during multiplayer.ArmA 3 is a tactical shooter. Call of Duty or Battlefield fanboys go home. It is one of the most authentic combat simulators available to the public. It is not perfect, however. For what ArmA 3 lacks in realism and authenticity, it makes up for with a better physics engine, improved  bullet ballistics, better graphics, ragdoll physics and an even bigger map. ArmA 3, like most of its Bohemia Interactive siblings, and many other games on the market, is a dish best served multiplayer. It's a very squad-based, team-work orientated warfare experience. You CAN go lone wolf rambo; there is nothing stopping you. However, you should be prepared to die very quickly and you may negatively impact both you and your teammates with your actions. In multiplayer, make sure you have all sectors covered and that you've got your teammates backs. Every squadmember is a vital asset, and if you screw up your whole team will pay the price. It's not about the points, it's about the mission. You cease to be a player; from the moment you join a server your mentality should be that you are a cog in the war machine. Be the best you can be; weigh your options, play tactically and, if you're lucky, you might 'Survive', 'Adapt' and 'Win'.The AI is somewhat disappointing, can be extremely inconsistent. Sometimes you can run right past them and they will not notice you. Other times, they will detect and headshot you from 500m away, first shot, in the middle of the night and fog all around. This seems to have improved since the Alpha release of the game, however. The AI is often fairly consistent in its behaviour. They are not to be treated as the weak AI you might storm through in other games. While they often are incapable of matching the abilities of a skillful player, the AI an often deadly foe. Respect the AI, and try to put yourself in their shoes. While you may cry 'bull****!' when an AI kills you, were you the AI shooting at the player that is yourself, I am sure it not seem so ridiculous and their shots so impossibly accurate anymore. Stick to cover, stay calm and don't do anything stupid. Use your teammates to help you (or try... public servers can get messy). If you want to enjoy ArmA 3 to the fullest, I would definately suggest seeking out and joining a 'Realism Unit'. Realism units are player groups which emulate the battlefields of today (and even some which are chronologically seperate from today). There, you will hopefully find organised, structured, tactical and authentic gameplay. If, like most people, that is what brought you to the ArmA series, a Realism Unit is where you belong.One thing ArmA has always had is a vast modding community, and fans are constantly producing and releasing more content. A modification I am particularly looking forward to is the Advanced Combat Environment (more commonly known as ACE2, the sequal to ACE for the original ArmA: Armed Assault game) mod for ArmA 3. In ArmA 2, which utilised a more realistic feeling, simulator-ish, yet more restrictive engine, I had a lot of fun with ACE. It adds lots of functionality and added realism, and helps to expand the world of Arma. The 'Authentic Gameplay Modification' (AGM) and Comabt Space Enhancement (CSE) were two realism mods which expanded the gameplay significantly, which have since been discontinued. Their teams have merged, along with some of the developers from ACE2, to develop the recently announced ACE3. As of your reading this, ACE3 is probably already released and one of the most widely used mods in the ArmA III modding scene.Perhaps one of the most appealing aspects of the ArmA series, and one that gives it such longevity and popularity, would be the powerful mission editor tools. On the Steam Workshop, and several other online websites, you can find both Singleplayer and Multiplayer community-made missions with varying difficulties and talent. The ALiVE mod for ArmA 3 allows mission makers to easily build large-scale, dynamic, evolving missions utilising procedural generation, helping to flesh out the ArmA experience.I am excited to see what ArmA IV will bring to the table, if Bohemia Interactive decide to create a fourth installment in the series. They probably will, and I do think the first thing they will need to work on if they want to have a snowball's chance in hell of selling an ArmA 4, would be the AI. It isn't bad, but it is far from good and needs some massive improvement.

It is one of the few games I play that I continue to come back to over and over again.I won't go into much of the stuff you can read about online through professional reviews; stuff like the mechanics, graphics, etc. What I will go over though is why exactly this game is a gym despite any short comings and why it has such a loyal community.Arma is a game that scales with your imagination. While not necessarily easy, users can create whatever mod they want for this game. Just recently I saw a video for a T-Rex mod.T-Rex aside, many of the modders for this game take it upon themselve to implement items and equipment into the game that the developers could not (most likely for legal purposes/trademarks). Missions are made constantly so there is never a worry of running out of something to do in Arma 3.With one of the largest maps, realistic ballistics, and a sometimes brutally hard AI, the game provides a sandbox for players to play whatever military simulation they could every desire.Games can be designed to have a small 4 man team infiltrating small enemy camps or they can be designed to have huge operations with several platoons, armored vehicles, and airsupport.My only warning would be to take your time learning the game and the modding community. When I first purchased Arma 2, I didn't play it for a year after my initial play through because I didn't quite 'get' the game. content:
Posted: August 5, 2016
												Arma 3, where do I start? I guess I'll start with my first ever experience with the game.I've always watched allot of Arma 3 Life videos and those where my main reason I bought the game, but after I bought it I found out that I was too young to be whitelisted on an Arma 3 Life server so I started playing allot of Wasteland together with my friend who had also bought Arma 3, it was so much fun that I had 80 hours in the first 5 days and over 200 hours in the first month! After playing some Wasteland together we decided to play some Altis Life, I've got so much to tell you about Altis Life and I've met so many awesome people who I still play with today, at first I was just playing with me and my friend and we were just walking/driving around doing some copper buying rooks like every hobo. When we were on our way to buy a rook we came across a fellow hobo who had crashed his car, he was really nice and we decided to make a gang with the 3 of us, this is the beginning of the gang Original Hobos, we quickly started growing and started making more money with bigger trucks and did more illegal stuff like selling drugs, we had quite a big gang setup with quite some people but then Altis Life started boring, I quit for a while but not too long ago I came back, met loads of new people, Joined HATO (Highway Agency), NHS (Medics) and APC (Police) I really enjoy playing as APC and its loads of fun aswell as playing as a medic, I would say about 350 hours I've played are in Altis Life, I'm currently running around with an MXM with DMS and fully geared and 3 million in the bank, I earn about 1 million per day in the APC.This game is so much fun and I would reccomend this to anyone. This isn't just a millitary shooter, It's everything. Mod change the whole way the game works and make it a completely new game. Exile is also a very good mod, It's a bit like Rust but with loot that you can pick up from the ground, and there is allot of loot on the ground if you just walk around a city for about 15 mins you'll be fully geared and ready to take on other players and sell some loot for more poptabs to buy more stuff at the traders.There's just so much to say about this game that I can't be bothered to write it all down.I'd reccomend this game to ANYONE this game fits any gamer. Don't like playing King Of The Hill? Try out a different gamemode.One final thing I am going to talk about is Zeus.Zeus allows you to create your own missions while other players play it, it's a real-time mission editor while the players are already playing the mission, it's kinda hard to explain but try it out yourself.Oh almost forgot, if you buy this game then I really reccomend buying the Apex bundle, Apex is a BIG expansion with a new map lots of new vehicles and it's a must have.Feel free to add me on steam and if you need some help on Altis Life (grandtheftarma.com) send me a message I will get you hooked up with some money, a truck and some tips.

content:
Posted: August 28, 2016
												This game started rough in the alpha, but since then I've come to consider this as the greatest shooter of all time. I could gush about it for hours, but I'll keep it to pros and cons.Pros:-Easily the most realistic shooter ever made-Beautiful graphics-Great dev who embraces the community and mods-Least asinine DLC scheme I've seen-Regular updates that greatly improve the game-Mods. If you dream it, there's a mod for it-Best soundscape of any game I've played-Nails the feel of shooting and moving with firearms better than any other game-Almost all flaws from previous games have been improved-Large mutliplayer community-Difficulty, interface, every control, visuals, and AI are fully configurable to your taste. AI too accurate? You can change that-Gigantic maps that 400 hours later I still haven't even covered half of-Unique moments and battles that can't take place in other scripted shooters-Mission editor allowing for literally any kind of gameplay-There's not enough time in a life to explore all official and user missions and modsCons:-Extremely hardware demanding. Get yourself a good processor  --Core i5 4690k @ 4 ghz / GTX 970 OC'd gets 40 FPS on average, but regularly dips to 20  --You'll also want an SSD. Standard hard drives will give you occasional 1-2 second freezes-You will run into bugs, mostly with how missions play out-Commanding friendly AI is extremely clunky. Improvements have been made but total overhaul is needed. C2 Command mod mostly alleviates this-AI is difficult to implement when creating missions-Mission scripting is difficult and confusing. There is a full wiki and forum dedicated to it but they don't help much-While the devs are wonderful, the community is elitist and less than helpfulPick this game up. Seriously. It's worth every single penny.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 5, 2016
												This game is nothing but amazing!10/10Pro's : 1.Graphics2.Gameplay3.Endless PossibilitiesThe graphics in this game are down right amazing as long as you are playing on something higher than low the graphics will not look like someone♥♥♥♥♥♥on your computer monitor! The Gameplay is downright amazing there are so many things you can do with this game it's insane, From flying in a helicopter and protecting your fellow teamates to putting your boots on the ground to help out your teamates and eliminate enemies together. As far as realism goes this game is doing amazing. Then comes the endless possibilities! With all these hours in this game I have had some time to mess around with the game whether it be adding mods to the game or going against AI with my friends on multiple servers that offer the fun and tactical gameplay! I enjoyed Wasteland, Altis Life, Arma 3 Life etc. But what really made me enjoy the game was the servers that had there own little touch to the game that made the game feel different, That's why I had so much fun adding mods to the game and enjoyed things like Arma 3 Life when it was popular and stuff around those areas where fun to me and I'm sure they can be fun to you! This game is a whole lot a fun and worth the buy 100% but with such an amazing game there of course has to be some cons to it because no game is ever perfect. Cons: Minor glitches in the game like being able to see through walls to flying sky high into outer space are only a few of the minor glitches that can be found in this game, None of the glitches are enough to make you rethink buying the game or enough to make you uninstall it and never want to play it again but for the rare amount of times that it happens it can get really annoying. Another problem that this game has is the lag that it creates because of how good the graphics are, Although I don't get the massive amount of lag that some people get I do hear people complaining about how the lag kills there computer and there is just no point in playing the game. Although the lag is annoying at times as long as you have a good computer the game won't kill you as much the game can be run on a decent computer hell I used to run it on an old computer I got from Best Buy years ago! The game in general is not the problem for your lag it is the servers and the fact that so much stuff is happening at the same time that it causes you to lag and if the server doesn't restart frequently then you might want to find a new server. It's all a matter of finding a server that you enjoy and you feel as if you can play on it even if it does lag you a little, I have yet to meet someone that doesn't have a super computer that doesn't have minor lag in the game and that is the only problem with the game if you don't have a decent computer you might as well not even bother wasting your money and your time. After reading that I hope you understand how fun this game can be as long as you are sure than your computer can handle such a heavy game! If you do get the game I hope you enjoy it and get as much hours as I did into the game or maybe even more. The realism is waiting for you!

content:
Posted: February 26, 2014
												If Call of Duty is a Hollywood "military porn" movie, and Battlefield is the docudrama on military subjects, Arma is the trip down to the local military base, spending time on the range and on the obstacle course, and learning the real deal from the real people. Its about as close as you can get without signing up.Arma 3 is a sandbox infantry simulator with a focus on authenticity, set in a near-future ficticious scenario of 2035, wherein NATO is but a shadow of its former (aka: current-day) self, and a new enemy of Iranian origin begins a localized takeover of a small collection of islands in the Agean Sea, leading to a potential "flashpoint" of a wider war between NATO-allied nations near the Medittereanean and the Iranian-led "CSAT" forces, with Greek-based freedom fighters and the Greek army caught inbetween.There is a large focus (stemming from 4 games prior, not including expansions) on realism, and not the Hollywood "realism" that Call of Duty or Battlefield would throw at you. This game has proper modelling of terminal ballistics (range, ballistics drop, penetration, deflection, windage), proper modelling of the kilometers of distances you'll oftentimes have to travel, proper weapons, vehicles, and equipment modelling and mechanics, and proper tactics and strategy implementation.How proper? Well the seminal game of the series, let alone this infantry simulator genre, was the penultimate "Operation Flashpoint" of 2001 (now named Arma: Cold War Assault), which led to the development of the Virtual Battlespace 1 and 2 interactive training simulator aids that are currently being used by world militaries around the world, alongside the next games in the series (with the new name), Armed Assault (or Arma).Whilst there is a singleplayer campaign of due note (and one that is highly recommendable to newcomers to the series as the campaign since Arma 1 has always been structured to deliver a solid singleplayer experience at the same time introduce and teach the fundamental mechanics of the game), the real focus of the game is in its sandbox nature, allowing a very fanatic and vibrant community to create missions of all kinds, oftentimes with a multiplayer bent, for the game. Many of these missions are in the Steam Workshop, a first for the series.The multiplayer aspect of this game is extensive and ranges from straight-up "hardcore" simulation fanatics, exercising proper military procedures, tactics, and actions, to GTA-like -Life servers, Wasteland (read: DayZ in Arma), and everything in between (Insurgency, and Domination/Invade&Annex). In fact, many of the aformentioned gameplay types are all community-born, with the different communities that play Arma oftentimes having vastly different variants of each type, with many having a lot of bleed-over into each other, or being a singular experience on their own. One's multiplayer experiences are oftentimes directly tied to the quality of the people that share the same experience with you, and Arma's many communities are a notch above the expected grade, with all kinds from laid-back to straight-up, oftentimes with people who are former and even current serving military. You wont feel alone if you look around, and the people you will find are of all kinds, many for the better.This game is highly recommended to those who feel that Battlefield is not a solid enough experience and want to get deeper into the mindset of a soldier in a more authentic worldspace, and want to see how and why military tactics of today work they way they work, from close-quarters battle (CQB) in room clearing, to urban MOUT combat and open areas, to infantry - mechanized - armor - air interplay and supports.
