number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 24, 2016
												WowI've played 500+ hours on this game and I'm still not bored of it. The game throws you into the battlefield with no help at all, in fact it can be a little confusing at your first minutes of play. But once you dedicate yourself and learn the Art of War, you will soon be talking, what almost seems alien language, to others in your house. From your usual mainstream happy-go-lucky Call of Duty or Battlefield, Arma 3 teaches you the realism of war by simulating... WAR. It will be frustrating, it will be dirty and it will rewarding! You can either get into multiplayer (strategic and friendly for the best part), single player (which has a good campaign at the same time introducing you to what you will be heading into for the rest of the game) and editor (a huge sandbox where you can do anything and make anything such as missions, mods, and just mess around to get used to the gameplay and physics).Absolutely love this game and totally recommend it for veterans and people who are interested in the whole military theme.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 22, 2014
												Buy it and start with the Battle Royale mod (which is excellent for both solo and coop play) if you like super tactical shooters with roaming like far cry/crysis games. The map is 270 km2 and super varied so the encounters are always different. I've played 110+ hours and i still haven't seen everything on the map. I experience immersion in this game like nothing else i have played for a long time. There is a lot of potential in the mods. The value is good because it's future proof due to mods and updates. You can really stress out your high-end rigs with this game, and the optimization isn't terrible - it runs better than Arma 2 and Dayz. I tried the game with a 7 year old rig and it was playable. The game is pretty much reliant on mods so you should be prepared to install some, they are easy to install thoughThe game is definitely not bug-free at this time, and the physics are questionable. You'll get stuck inside rocks and walls, shoot invisible obstructions, and die some unfair deaths. The controls are also really technical, so it is best for hardcore and patient players, maybe as an evolution from Battlefield-like games

content:
Posted: September 13, 2013
												This game is an incredibly good one, but like past bohemia works it has a long path ahead of it. Do not go into the Steam Community Hub for this game, it is a disgusting look at overrivliged and spoiled children who don't understand how the game works they expect it to run like triple-A action shooters. The Reality is Arma is a military Simulator: your character can get hurt from non combat experience, he will become incredibly exhausted after running and carrying heavy gear, one bullet from any range can cause him to bleed out, it take time and patience to make a shot over 500m away. The vehicle combat requires multiplayer players, if your driving you'll need a gunner and a crew chief to spot targets for the gunner. Helicopters are fragile and take practice for good maneuvering and landing. Part of combat is the journey from your base to the AO, it can be anywhere from 2-25+ minutes of NO combat.To enjoy this game you need to give it time, The studio is still releasing content (FREE CONTENT) on an almost bi-weekly basis. If you don't like the game than I recommend keeping quiet about and maybe return in a year or two. For better opinions on arma 3 go to the arma 3 community website, this steam hub is just a cesspool, much like how the A2:OA hub turned into a DayZ orgy a year ago

content:
Posted: February 8, 2016
												UPDATE:I believe its time to update this review as this game and its community have become part of my daily life. Since my original review, I have upgraded my computer and Arma 3 runs really well, keep in mind that CPU is more important for this game than GPU. I have joined a wonderful Arma unit since then, I have invested in a head tracking system and voice commanding software and the experience in Arma 3 and Arma 2 that I recently also purchased both for its campaign and also for the DayZ mod is unsurpassed by any other tactical milsim FPS. This game will reward you in many ways, from the incredible campaign and feel of the in-game environment to the friends you are going to make playing this game on public servers and with your team unit (you should definitely join an Arma unit to enjoy the game at its fullest). Just give it a try and you'll fall in love with it.Original review:I had this game on my mind for a long time now, but I was divided by the reviews on Steam, on Web and also from trying the Arma 2 Demo. I tell you now, I regret for waiting for so long, I regret for not playing Arma 2, I regret for not playing Arma 1.This game is fantastic, is the pinnacle of the tactical squad shooters.First things first:If you tried the Arma 2 Demo and was buggy and choppy and freezy for you, don't connect these two games, Arma 3 has nothing to do in performance compared to Arma 2(and in graphics). It playes fine on my PC on High settings, though I have disabled AA,PP,AO, but it still is perfectly beautiful.My hardware is:i5-3550 3.0 GHZAMD HD Radeon 6870 1 GB16 GB Ram500 GB SSDAbout the reviews:People saying that this game is a sim, it's not a sim. DCS world is a sim. In Arma 3 you can fly and drive any vehicle with easiness. This does not mean that the game is arcade of course. It's just not a sim in the way other sims are. In the infantry emulation sector it's perfect, it feels like you are out in the fields.Gameplay wise is a great sandbox with perfect ballistics, physics, dynamics, graphics.If you liked Rainbow Six Ghost Recon, Rainbow Six Vegas,  S.W.A.T. 4, Insurgency, then it's your next step.If you can buy it with the DLC Bundle, do so its totally worth it, I had extremelly fun with kart racing, something I couldn't imagine.If you have a xbox controller it's worth it to set it up for vehicles, it will make handling them even more easy.If you want the best experience and immersion play the game in Elite difficulty with every help disabled, it Rocks.Bear in mind that this game is life consuming. It's world siphons you in.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 4, 2013
												About the game background: In 2001 the game Operation Flashpoint was made for the PC, it followed the Cold War era fighting between America and Soviet Russia. Due to copyright names in 2007 Bohemia Interactive created Armed Assault or ArmA. ArmA was followed up in 2009 with ArmA 2. Now in 2013 the fourth game is out. Armed Assault 3 is set in the near future of 2035 where NATO forces are pitted with a equally powerful foe. Gameplay: ArmA 3 is a very fast paced realistic shooter. With smooth controls and advance movement and stance options. The biggest feature is modualr gear and weapons. The ability to switch scopes, vests, or anything else on the fly to help protect you or assist you in combat sets this game apart from anything else. The AI in ArmA are ruthless and relentless, with advance path finding and adjustable skill they are able to hunt you, flank you, and take cover from you. Multiplayer: The game supports missions with over 80 players! Everything from Death Match, cooperative, team, squad, and unit missions. With the new physics system weapons are more realistic and so is the damage. The Community: ArmA's community is one of the strongest around. Skilled missions makers release daily content. Amazing Modders make new addons that completely change the way the game is played. Final words: While I personally enjoy this game, I do understand it has a lot of content that has not been added (yet). The development is always working on the game, and  adding more conent but in its current state it only has half the units, weapons, and vehicles of its predecessor. Graphics: 9/10 Gameplay: 8.5/10Story: 5/10 (next DLC will add more story content)Multiplayer: 9/10Overall: 8.5/10 Worth every penny.

content:
Posted: July 5, 2014
												Arma is a game that takes a type of person to like it.  It has its glitches, and its awesome things.  Altis Life is something you should check out if you are more of a casual RP player.  If you are more serious, try out a mil sim server where literally everything is simulated like the military.  There are also domination servers where you capture towns from enemy NPC forces.  If you have no patience, there is always wasteland, or king of the hill, where you can shoot people on sight without worry of a ban.  Personally I think arma is a great game.  I would give it a 8.5/10 due to the "arma glitches" and learning curve.  They are working on fixing the learning curve though.   I would like to see more out of the devs, even though I believe they are working hard.  Most of my time is from playing on an altis life server - Therevolutiongaming.  Now that it has closed down I play other gamemodes like exile, KOTH, or random missions with friends.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
												As a veteran of both Battlefield and CoD Franchises, I can say that this game WIPES THE FLOOR with BOTH of them. Due to recent computer upgrades I can finally dive into this franchise and experience what all my friends have talked about for years. Yes this game has its glitches, bugs, crashes, ect.. But then again, what game doesn't(yes even TF2)? I have got to say this is a game that you either LOVE IT or HATE IT, and since this game keeps me up till 3 a.m. and gives me hours of mindless fun(giving a reason why Special Forces is "Special"), keeping me on my toes(on my butt and my head down), nearly endless mods and player created content that are added everyday to keep the game fresh, and giving a sense of realism that Battlefield or CoD can't.. This isn't any casual shooter that you can run at the enemy and expect them not to hit you and you suddenly regenerate health, this makes you feel like you're at war.. Should you buy it? Thats up to you and your bank account, but in the long run, it's completly worth it..

content:
Posted: March 7, 2014
												Do I recommend this game? Yes I do. If you are coming from console shooters, then the pace might be way too slow for you. But I recommend you stick with it: once you get over the adjustment, you will be rewarded with some really memorable moments.  I found my way in to this series with Arma:Gold, which still looks great to this day. They all feature the same basic framework: large open world, your choice of weapon/vehicle/aircraft and a powerful editor for creating your own missions. This is why it appeals to lots of us, because you may have had Airfix soldiers when you were younger, where you set up battles on your bed, using the folded quilt as custom topography. Arma taps into that part of you, giving you the tools to create your own stories. The only limit is your imagination.Other reviewers here Im sure will have commented on the other game modes, so I dont think I need to review them again.Prerequisites to enjoy this game are: 1) Patience, you need to learn the controls, and dont expect to be firing your weapon at enemies every second. You sometimes will have to travel large distance by foot. 2) A PC that exceeds the requirements. It looks fantastic. 3) Toy soldiers as a kid.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												I really can't say enough positive things about ARMA in general, or ARMA III specifically.  This is a carefully crafted, technically ambitious, loveably flawed addition to a long and growing line of similarly awesome titles.  This is certainly NOT the game for a more relaxed gamer.  Players need skill, focus, and practice if they are going to be an asset to their team, not to mention lots of patience.  If you're a gamer looking for a quick-fix, I'd point you elsewhere, as there are plenty of great games out there for that kind of experience.  If you're looking for a slow-burn thinking-man's shooter with an immense scope and unforgiving simulation, then ARMA is a great place to go.  If you preferred the early Rainbow Six games over Counter Strike and Unreal Tournament, then you'll find yourself right at home with ARMA's dedication to realism.  It's not perfect by any means; it's ambition to cover the full spectrum of combined-arms warfare at the tactical level means no one area has a truly complete simulation, but the love of the subject matter by the developers oozes out of every frame, and the darn near limitless possibilities for adventure thanks to the built-in mission editor keep me coming back no matter how many times a rogue AI squadmate or uncooperative mission objectives force me to ALT-F4.  To top it all off, ARMA has one of the most active, mature, and dedicated modding communities I've seen in a long, long time, a product of the type of player a game like ARMA attracts.  The development company has shown itself to be a classy, player-orientated organization with pretty solid business ethics and a respect for our choice, as gamers, to spend our free time with their products.  If you're interested in ARMA III, check out ARMA II, its predecessor.  A free version is available on STEAM, and it can give you a solid idea of whether or not this is the game for you.TL;DR: Fantastic game for realism junkies.  9/10.

content:
Posted: December 15, 2013
												While it's definitely lacking in content as of yet, the developers are constantly pushing out more and more to add to the game as time goes on. It has sleek graphics and very realistic gameplay; incidentally, if you're looking for Call of Duty or Battlefield with tight corners and insanely over-powered guns and dumbed-down ballistics, you, sir, have come to the wrong place.As said by Runekn so perfectly:"Arma is not a game which you pick up at launch, play the campaign and a bit of mp, and then trow away. You buy it, love it or hate it, and then play it forever or trow it away immediately."The community is incredibly active, and if the game is missing something (a jet, or faction, or gun), there are modders out there currently hard at work making this game more incredible.At the time of writing, the first of three campaign episodes have come out, the next slated for early next year. The game is becoming more and more intricate as people "leave" ARMA II to rest for a bit while they pursue ARMA III and more Scenarios are being made (thanks to Workshop Integration). Overall, this is an excellent game, and if you're sick of CoD or BF, need a dose of excitement or realism, or just need a satisfying filler while the sequel [of CoD or BF] comes out, ARMA III will give the experience yourself looking for.

content:
Posted: September 30, 2015
												This game is really quite good. It wholly deserves the 60 dollar price in my opinion, and that is true to form. There has been a huge amount of work put into the game. Its scale and the seriousness with which it was handled by its developers absolutely deserves them the full 60 dollars. This game puts even next gen games to the test. It is fantastic. I will relay some of my experiences with the game:Personally I am a HUGE fan of the lighting in the game. The dark is really dark, and the light is really light. The light is in fact just beautiful. There is nothing like driving in the night with your headlights on, and stopping somewhere with the light of your headlights to work by. Or moving through the dark in the morning, with a flashlight and a lighthouse far above you to keep things clear. Even tracers are quite well done, and you will constantly be taken aback by the absolute beauty and accuracy of both the lighting and the environment.On to the environment. The environment is enormous. Hills, plains, farmland, valleys. It is all very well designed and is covered by very accurate and realistic looking flora which all server the purpose of providing some very useful and much needed cover. The scale of things is just huge, and is enough to blow ones mind. It is really something, standing on a hill 1 km away from an enemy platoon on the face of another and exchanging fire. That is what battle is, and that is really the scale that stands true to the test as what Arma is really about.The vehicles are also a great part of the game, they are all EXTREMELY meticulously designed, and appear to be very much the real thing. In some ways, different, but you will not mind your long commutes via chopper or land solely because of the eye candy that is your ride.The gunfire is a bit disappointing, however. Firing ones gun is not as much a pleasure as it may be in other games. It does not convey the same detail or intricate beauty that other parts of the game do, and does not feel nearly so powerful. I am not sure as to why this might be, but the guns are just so... light. I would like to see some more impressively realistic muzzle flare and gun interaction.Additionally, the AI in the game is very flawed and can certainly leave one disappointed, especially during showcase missions. When I would like to play with a fully interactive AI, I meet soldiers who are completely unresponsive, downright born with autism and having a heart attack, or are just altogether far too quick to respond and accurate, just like a robot. The AI opponents often leave one shaking their head at the huge holes in interactability, especially on missions where otherwise this would be the focus of the game.In total, however, the game is huge. If you are interested in the sort of fully fledged MILSIM combat that this game has to offer, please get it. I assure you that there is nothing else like this out there, and this is a game of its own. The creators had a mission, and that mission was achieved. Be responsible when you are flying your intricately designed helicopters or blazing tracer rounds at enemy soldiers down the ravine. Its fun stuff, and you never know where that may lead.

content:
Posted: May 26, 2016
												Simulation isn't the defining aspect of Arma. It's scale.The enormity of the map is the foundation for the experiences that distinguish Bohemia Interactive's flagship franchise. It's what makes radios, topographical maps, binoculars, and compasses practical equipment in an FPS. It's what allows for kilometer-long headshots and coordinated convoy raids. It's what makes using your eyes to spot hints of enemies--muzzle flashes, tracers, gunsmoke--as valuable as being a crack shot.The scale of Arma 3 dwarfs everything in the genre, including Arma 2. Altis, a keyhole portion of which is seen in these screenshots, is a Mediterranean island-nation assembled from ruins, airports, coastal villages, solar power plants, military outposts, salt flats, and tank-friendly scrubland. It's a variegated backyard for you to play war in, but what's more significant is that Arma's landscape finally has the technology it deserves.

content:
Posted: April 29, 2014
												this game has many modified servers making it worth every penny, and even though it has a full inventory of vehicles it is incredibly difficult to stop playing even if you change server it has details you will not find in most games of its kind. on different servers and on singleplayer mode it is not a walkover, and you are challenged with the full feel and suppression war brings with good graphics quality  and huge map enviroments citys and towns to explore. i feel as this game should win more awards just for the playability alone and incredibly varied choice of things to do in game its quite simply  never ending ,  the maps are very very big. 20km  what game makes you travel that distance and your still not quite where you want to be .there is always a little more to see with all the mods that are being done in multiplayer  £20 this cost me on a pre release alpha . the best money i have ever spent so much so i bought 4 friends a copy of this game ....... and ive never done that in 30 years of gaming.update ....the amount of hours i have put into arma 3 is over 4000 now  mainly on one multiplayer server .but having tried many i feel happy with the life servers . ALTIS LIFE at  ts @ sealteamsloth.comthe life servers replicate working robberies, bank heists and many both legal and  illegal activities .an all round well blanced community helps . but hard to keep trhat way at times with new people just not reading the rules ,copying  their watched videos and trolling to no end . hysterical at times the wasteland is an obvious military style  game type with an arsenal of weapons  to be found by scavenging around the island  then by team blue or red you take the fight to the enemy . or you go solo in greenfor killing anyone in sight . so a more single minded tactical strategy is needed to survive .  one can get weapons by buying them at often with enemy watching gunstores .so an all round awareness is needed to get in and get out alive as its often a sniper haven area . the sights on your weapon are vital to success at distances exceeding 200 metres or more .and can be found around the islands and gunstores .the ability to get your soldier to settle before shooting in distance fire is needed to aim accurately.i cannot stress this enough at long range shooting distances.often a soldier on the slow move is the best at distance and close up contact . but it is terrain dependant also . the best way to find out your weakness is to play on a public game server .with the weapons of your choice . one has to just get in the game to get better at it .  map, navigation and compass are vital tools to easily find your destination and objectives .strategy is needed on most game modes and servers with many choices and decisions to make a quick game experience of  different game servers will help you improve your skills .the ARMA£editor, is a a 3d enviroment now with many tactical options and decisions to be made .with arma 3 you can play for a year and still not be anywhere near completion of the game .it is the best money i have personally ever spent on a game . there are always new mods and options to try new servers with arma 3 .one just has to get into the role and read the rules set by the server where applicable or needed. many servers have admins watching / playing which helps out a lot with issues and glitches we find as arma 3 progresses to a better experience for us  all.  failures .glitchy actions sometimes the occasional lying down to stand glitch can happen . but overall a great experience when using teamspeak which is free to download as a communication aid between you and your team .  there is other in game communications and chat one can use . task force radio  being one also.my first server i ever played on was an american server an experience i cant forget . the bravado and communication skills are needed to communicate in a effective manner  so a microphone is needed for quicker communication in your team or group, even groups can communicate individually and between each other with channel commander and task force radio options .sound .well you will need to adjust your sound options turning down the music and renaming your soldier in your profile to suit your batallion or group  you play with . optional. in profile .some servers have built in ear supression  by pressing a few keys together so only chat can be heard.  and other sounds reduced .in game view distances are a helpful aid also to aid in viewing enemys so adjust accordingly between playability and safety. graphical quality ... arma 3 will use whatever you throw at it and you can still not get full view distances unless you use the top graphics cards out there and often in sli or dual configurations .but anything from an NVIDIA 750ti or higher should help more .the Nvidia 970 is  best for price today so dual cards will beat a 980 but not on GDDR5 memory as it cancels to 4 gig on the 970.so be warned  get a good system with intel 4th generation or above  i5 or i7 series cpu, to get the best from arma3 .yes 6th genertion cpu,s will beast this game the 6700k is probably the best option. today .but not needed  should you not have it you will still gain by using a high core cpu  even on AMD systems one can have a great experience for less money as many gamers do . quad core  4ghz is a fair balance as arma 3 is cpu intensive. on 1 core , but one can change the pc options to perform better should one need to.a good sound program is vital if you need to survive long on arma 3 , but not absolutely vital to play the game .  5.1 0r 7.1 headsets are a bonus and work just  on lesser priced pc,s through the usb or front jack options. razer are an effective way to quickly gain surround sound in game and the higher priced turtle beaches are an option also but if im fussy i would use the Astro A40 or astro A50 to get some real sound quality to the game .so the learning curve is high when coming from battlefied 3 or 4 or counter strike  games .but the footstep function can save you or your team  if you have it  in close town battles .a well coordinated team policy is just part of the excellence that arma can provide when engagements are in your sights .the game updates are just an important  part of playing arma so do it often or when they are shown.see you on the game if you have the right stuff. you probably do ,and if you do not .you soon will.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2015
												One of the most fun games out in the steam store. There's so much variety that inlcudes mods and different gamemodes. Even though simulator games are not your type you can still find a place in Arma. You can play gamemodes ranging from all of the Life mods (Altis Life, Arma 3 Life, etc), King of the Hill, Domination (coop Players vs. AI), Wasteland, Epoch, Exile, Breaking Point, Battle Royale, and many more. Those are just multiplayers mods and gamemodes you can play, there is also a huge variety of mods and missions available in the workshop that you can download and play nonstop. All of this available in huge maps, such as Altis that is around 260 sq km.Every day, whatever you play, you will always experience something new. Be it either encountering a Wipeout for the first time, getting Allahu Akbar'd at Kavala Square in Altis Life, robbing a bank, being the most powerful group in a Wasteland server, meeting random people and start chaos around Altis, etc. There are just so many things you can do in Arma, the possibilities might be endless. I really recommend this game for anyone who is looking to have a unique experience. One thing though, playing with other people together in a group or clan is 1000 times more recommendable to get the most out of the experience.First Experiences in Altis Life:-Spawn in Kavala-No gear, only hello kitty clothes-Walk in the street-Spot a offroad piled with rebels shooting in the air being chased by 10 police cars-Walk into Kavala Square-Find half the server there (around 40 people)-Police don't know how to control the crowd-People jumping off buildings demanding money-Circle of guys smoking week with Bob Marley music-Sudden shout of "ALLAHU AKBAR"-The whole Kavala Square gets leveled-Everyone dies-Spawn again-Offroad pulls up, guy says to take a gun-Grab gun from the offroad with 5 other people-Do a 10 min stealth mission around Kavala to avoid cops with the 5 guys-Plan out a robbery-PUT YOUR HANDS UP-Turns out to be an officer-Turns around, spam tazes-Restrained-Go to jail for 15 minutes-10/10 would Altis Life again

content:

												Unique game. This doesn't count as a shooter, its a military simulator, but with good reason. The term "shooter" is used loosely to designate any game with guns. In this game, understanding military language, logistics, and tactics is just as important as having enough ammo and good aim. I rate this game highly, but don't walk into this expecting guns ablazing and being an insane tank able to take down platoons of dudes. It's for its own crowd, it's up to you to figure out if you are/want to be part of that crowd.

content:
Posted: July 25, 2015
												This game... Well, the story is: if you hope for a campaign, it's here, but it is one of the worst i've played - after 5 hours of a "meh" 1st campaign, comes the second one, where a greek insurgent has a terrible accent... polish, to be exact (no racism against poles, i am one, and our accent does sound awful). But the multiplayer - as addictive as it can get. Good balance when it comes to co-op - it always is a challenge to beat the ai. Though it does obviously have some bugs, sometimes.Pros:- Fresh and new compared to BF and CoD... and in my opinion somehow better than both.- Quite good graphics- A nice choice of weapons in MP... though there could be more- A LOT of creativity from the devs- Finally, a truly team-based FPS- A lot of customisability for your character - though it's not Rainbow Six Vegas 2 level of it.Cons:- The campaign is crap - enemies hitting you from impossible angles, a pretty bad story... though better than CoD:G- Even if you have a beastly PC, there will be a frame rate drop when driving in vehicles if you have you view distance too high (as infantry, i use 8000 m, i have to use 1200 in vehicles)- Bugs bugs bugs... Though the devs patched a lot of them already.Overally, the game is a 9/10. It would be a 10/10 if the campaign was a tad better, and if not for bugs which actually hurt the gameplay (sinking into a pier when trying to climb it) it would be definitely the best FPS on the market. It is the best when it comes to team play and realism though. Definitly recommend.

content:
Posted: April 12, 2015
												I've played this game now for around 135 hours (1st of april 2016) and the reason for this is because, sadly, this is - I'm not going to use the word best because that doesn't really describe anything related to this game - the only available option for this kind of military "simulation".Sure there is Arma 2 but it is essentially the same game but worse graphics.So, the game is a broken♥♥♥♥♥piece of♥♥♥♥♥♥in which you have to scroll through menus to do♥♥♥♥♥♥which is very convenient when in the middle of a firefight, almost revolutionary I'd say. They could just do a radial wheel menu which has all the same options, and could be context sensitive so that the thing you most likely want to do when you point your gun at the door of a car when you are less than a foot away from it would pop up to the top of the radial wheel so you always know where the context sensitive action is on the wheel for quick access. Have reload and some other stuff at left, right and bottom of the wheel and fill in the gaps with something not so often used or let players even customize the menu themselves. Just doing this would make the managment of simple tasks like opening a door when you don't want to pick up that magazine that is under the car much easierInstead they still use menus which are small and you navigate them with your mouse wheel and the best part is when context sensitive stuff starts popping up on the menu things get really funny and it gets even better when you want to do things fast under pressure.Sure, you can use the "Use action key" but it does what it shows on the screen and that might not always be what you want to do, like my example of trying to open/close a door when there is an item in the doorway, in which case the game will most likely just make you pick up the item.Better start practicing that precision scrolling!A simulator where the cars explode(!) when you crash it into anything at high speeds, even a lamb fence is enough sometimes.This is a game made by devs who have never played any modern games and take all their inspiration from their own past games and the only one that they made that was considered "modern" was the original operation flashpoint back in 1998 or something.All their games after that have imitated OF and Arma 3 design is still based on that game (Read: doesn't work very well anymore, or never really did but it was the best they could do in -98)

												OK first things first. This game has endless possibilities, great campain, PVP modes king of the hill or wasteland, even better PVP in battleroyale, role playing games like altis life and arma 3 life, Zombie(dayz) mods like breaking point. In fact when you get arma its like you got 10 different games, which is awesome!My first day in altil life looked like this: i go get my licence, buy a car, get a delivery mission. I got one farest, like 26 kilometers acros altis. Got on a highway, after couple of miles, i crash into abandoned vehicle on the middle of the road without toolkit. Some guys found me on the road and gave me their truck so i could continue(awesome guys). Couple of miles ahead guy jumps in front of my truck trying to rob me, and he did robbed me. He walked back into his chopper and somehow insta chrashed(talk about insta karma?). I picked up his money and procced, only to be pulled over by a cop for speeding, he wrote me a ticket. Finally after 2 hours a got to my destination and delivered a package, i was so happy.10/10 would recommend to anyone!

												Arma is a game that takes a type of person to like it.  It has its glitches, and its awesome things.  Altis Life is something you should check out if you are more of a casual RP player.  If you are more serious, try out a mil sim server where literally everything is simulated like the military.  There are also domination servers where you capture towns from enemy NPC forces.  If you have no patience, there is always wasteland, or king of the hill, where you can shoot people on sight without worry of a ban.  Personally I think arma is a great game.  I would give it a 8.5/10 due to the "arma glitches" and learning curve.  They are working on fixing the learning curve though.   I would like to see more out of the devs, even though I believe they are working hard.  Most of my time is from playing on an altis life server - Therevolutiongaming.  Now that it has closed down I play other gamemodes like exile, KOTH, or random missions with friends.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												I really can't say enough positive things about ARMA in general, or ARMA III specifically.  This is a carefully crafted, technically ambitious, loveably flawed addition to a long and growing line of similarly awesome titles.  This is certainly NOT the game for a more relaxed gamer.  Players need skill, focus, and practice if they are going to be an asset to their team, not to mention lots of patience.  If you're a gamer looking for a quick-fix, I'd point you elsewhere, as there are plenty of great games out there for that kind of experience.  If you're looking for a slow-burn thinking-man's shooter with an immense scope and unforgiving simulation, then ARMA is a great place to go.  If you preferred the early Rainbow Six games over Counter Strike and Unreal Tournament, then you'll find yourself right at home with ARMA's dedication to realism.  It's not perfect by any means; it's ambition to cover the full spectrum of combined-arms warfare at the tactical level means no one area has a truly complete simulation, but the love of the subject matter by the developers oozes out of every frame, and the darn near limitless possibilities for adventure thanks to the built-in mission editor keep me coming back no matter how many times a rogue AI squadmate or uncooperative mission objectives force me to ALT-F4.  To top it all off, ARMA has one of the most active, mature, and dedicated modding communities I've seen in a long, long time, a product of the type of player a game like ARMA attracts.  The development company has shown itself to be a classy, player-orientated organization with pretty solid business ethics and a respect for our choice, as gamers, to spend our free time with their products.  If you're interested in ARMA III, check out ARMA II, its predecessor.  A free version is available on STEAM, and it can give you a solid idea of whether or not this is the game for you.TL;DR: Fantastic game for realism junkies.  9/10.

content:
Posted: March 24
												This game is a mix of feelings. A love - hate relationship if you will.        ----------TL;DR on the bottom-------------The game is amazing. Milsims, the mods, various gamemodes provided by Bohemia and the community.Sure, the community tends to be toxic and d*cks, especially in modes like Wasteland and other Co-ooperation gamemodes where you need to work as a team. But those people are most of the time easily ignored.The biggest downfall of this game, and i think every single person that has ever launched play on this game agrees, is the performance. It has gotten noticeably stable with x64 rolling out some time ago and that's helped the case a bit but overall it's still very, very, VERY un-enjoyable at times. Having spent 1.7k hours on this game i've spent most of my time playing with 30 FPS at average while my "rig" can easily reach over the minimum requirements. Speaking of which, thats one of the things that decieve players/buyers/users that are looking into buying a game such as this one, the requirements tab you find above the tab where you're reading this review. You know, that Minimum and Reccomended sys. requirements? Yeah, that's complete and utter bullsh*t. Maybe it couldve held true if the game had been optimised but at the moment of this review being written and before, everyone knows it's false as the statement that Russians despise of Vodka. Even the "beast-est" of rigs cannot run this game properly. The thing that YOU NEED in this game is single core performance, which can be achieved easily with overclocking your CPU. You may have six cores and octa cores but that's just extra numbers for the game to ignore, it barely uses 3-4 cores as it is. Like i said, SINGLE CORE PERFORMANCE is the key to achieving an enjoyable framerate. GPUs don't do much, other than help with textures and resolution settings, AO, AA , PPAA and so on.The gameplay is amazing, so much to choose from, from the campaign to the widely extensive  multiplayer mode that this game focuses on mainly. You have official modes such as Zeus, End Game and others and then you have modded modes such as Wasteland (which isnt really modded, it's just modified vanilla) and then Exile, which is an amazing mod btw, except for the bots that shoot you from a kilometer away from where they are and you haven't even came close to even looking at them. But that's only the top of the list. One mod of hundreds of thousands for you to choose from. Endless fun really, depending on what kind of action you prefer. Altough keep in mind that more mods sometimes equals lesser performance and ALOT of troubleshooting, unless you're lucky as hell.Movement is decent, alot of stances to choose from. Pretty much every one of the 3 main stances have atleast 2 "sub-stances" if you will. Play through bootcamp and or watch some videos or do the showcases that Bohemia provided for your education on how to properly play this game. Altough keep in mind, you can die from falling 5m off a ledge, and sometimes you can get glitched in certain terrain and die out of thin air.Mainly this game is alooooot of fun. Especially with friends. You get alot of shennanigans, mainly from some of the bugs and glitches this game has to "provide".This game has alot of those. Bugs and glitches. You can't play this game without experience most of them. You come to get used to them and overcome some of them, that are able to be overcome but there are some gamebreaking ones that just make you furious at times.Bohemia doesn't really care about all that much, i mean i hate to say it, they've made an amazing game but lately i dont know what's going on with their minds. From my perspective as i see it, they either don't know what they're doing or are just lazy as hell to do it anyways. You might experiece this very likely if you contact support regarding their product. You'l be asked to do some potential fixes to your problem but only find out that they give up after like 3 suggestions they provide for you and realise they dont work. There's a fair number of errors and glitches and crashes they've havent fixed and have been present for TOO. LONG. A great example of such error is UNABLE_TO_INIT_DXGI. The error has been present for nearly 2 years yet they haven't been even interested in acknowledging it's existence. They're completely ignoring these errors and not caring about them and just making DLCs instead of fixing their game to make it run smoother and more enjoyable.TL;DR : Game is great, decent ammount of bugs and glitches and errors the devs dont give a flying f*ck about to fix or deal with in general, lower than average performance, but the gameplay and shennanigans make it all worth it. You learn to love the lower performance compared to other games but the gameplay and shennanigans man. Priceless stuff :)

content:
Posted: May 16, 2016
												Arma 3 is an amazing game, however I'd reccomend doing your research before considering purchasing it. I personally am not a massive fan of "life" servers or that sorta thing, and I think public servers that try to be tactical are (with the exeption of a select few) mostly terrible. The base game has a decent ammount of content, but I personally can't deal with the AI and can't stand the single player. The BEST thing about Arma 3 is mods. Mods, Mods, Mods. Mods fix many of Arma's intrinsic problems and provide you with more content than you could ever want. It turns Arma from an okay-shooter to... well, pretty much anything. Life servers, Milsim groups, more relaxed tactical groups (my preference) - Arma 3 is the BEST sandbox shooter out there and, assuming there's something you're interested in, it's definately worth the price.

												Great game, I like the King of the Hill mode, they seem to be improving it really well. just a lot of buttons, and the steam workshop is a nice touch.Only downside is this games horriable engine. Once you start to add about 20 AI or players the engine starts to use the CPU or Video card less and less cuasing a performance drop. I seen maybe 30% CPU/GPU usage on a 106 player King of the hill match with 30 - 35fps hile on armory I can pull well into the 80's with a few players.Thats my only gripe about this game. If they would fix that then I would have no complaints at all.

content:
Posted: May 19, 2016
												It may look like "Hardcore millitary simulator" for someone, but actually, it has nothing to do with realism and simulation. Singleplayer campaign is sometimes frustrating, thanks to the stupid AI, but its not bad. Great thing is the new Eden Editor, where you can make your own scenarios, or just do funny stuff. But the real deal stands in Multiplayer, where you can choose from normal casual conflicts, to organizations/clans and MILSIM simualtions. The realism in vanilla game is almost like Battlefield, with little more options, but more laggy and unoptimized (Engine from 2001?). Irrespective of the LAZINESS from Bohemia Interactive. (example is the new Apex Expansion) Really small amount of Units/Factions and Weapons/Gear, so i highly recommend using mods. Overall I do recommend buying Arma III, if you have NASA PC and you're big fan of more open military action.

content:
Posted: July 10, 2016
												Bohemia Interactive Fans have been waiting 4 years for the next instalment of their most favourite PC open world military tactical Shooter franchise, Arma 3. Tacking place on the Aegean islands of Altis and Stratis of Greece with both Islands featuring the largess terrain of 290 km2 for any Arma game, Arma has never been so open world before. The islands features over 50 renamed villages with buildings that are both penetrable and destructible. The islands also include all sorts of kinds of wild life ranging from goats to grass snakes, bunnies to butterflies and even sharks and sea turtles in the surrounding waters. The republic of Altis and Stratis is populated by 5 unique factions that includes NATO and CSAT alongside the local AAF, FAIA gorillas and the civilian population. Each faction has their own motives, characteristics, vehicles and weapons.Arma 3 contains over 20 Vehicles including tanks, cars, helicopters, aircraft and quads that can be driven by players in the game. Plus, there is a selection of over 40 weapons to choose from that can be customised with their own types of scopes and other various types of attachments. Each type of weapons has its own handling, sway and recoil meaning that a Sub Machine gun is much easy to handle at close range then a sniper rifle. Arma 3 is so tactical, it features 15 types of stances that can be very useful in exposing the least amount of your body to the enemy. Although, Arma 3 has realistic ballistic penetration physics depending on weapon type, attachments, material, calibre and distance meaning that hiding behind a wooden fence or plaster wall may not really be a suitable type of cover. In Arma 3 you will have to be careful about how much weight you’re caring which can have effect on stamina. Arma 3 features a realistic night sky which can be useful when you are lost on Altis without a compass as the stars can be used to navigate. There is reasons why so many military veterans are into the Arma franchise. “Arma 3 makes Call of Duty look like a kid’s game.” If you’re a new player to Arma 3 and are intimidated by the large amount of complexity to such a realistic open world military tactical Shooter then you can start off with boot camp. Recently introduced in a free update it offers up a single payer tutorial campaign and virtual reality training topics.Arma 3's multiplayer is where the game really shines. Servers can have up to 100 players in all out warfare. Other than the vanilla game modes there is a bunch of community made game modes including the very popular DayZ zombie survival game mode. Arma 3 comes with a free DLC called Zeus which can be used create multiplayer scenarios from a birds eye view perspective. Arma 3 content creators also can easily create and save multilayer scenarios by using the in game scenario editor in a matter of minutes. Arma 3 content can be shared and downloaded over the steam workshop with over 10,000 scenarios and addons that have been published and is growing each day. There have been Arma 3 content creation contests with prizes veering from €20,000 to €200,000.Arma 3's new graphic engine unleashes the full potential of PC gaming. Fans will notice that the new real virtuality 4 engine Is great improvement over Arma 2's engine implementing all sorts of new changes with significant improvements to animations and sounds, combined with the introduction of Microsoft directx 11 and Nvdia physX™, the battlefields of Arma have never felt more real. However Despite being the 4th version of the real virtuality engine it’s still heavily based on the decade old Bohemia Interactive real virtuality game engine that is known for its poor optimisation leading to poor performance making it very demanding on PC hardware, epically when there are allot of AI’s.Arma 3 Averages reviews of 9/10 (55,000 being positive and only 6,000 negative) on steam. You can download the game now at a standard selling price of $39.99 USD off steam. Although, a steam sale would put a huge discount on the standard sale price if you choose to wait for one. I would recommend getting the Apex Edition as it’s come with all the DLC’s and the just recently released Apex expansion which is currently 20% of. With the game being constantly updated and having constant flow of community made content, the game is a must buy for any PC gamer. As expected for any Arma game it requires a very beathy gaming PC with both a powerful Graphics Card and processor so we recommend that you make sure that your system is well over the games system requirements before you make your purchase. A PC with an Intel core i7 processor and a strong graphic card along the lines of an Nvdia GTX 970 or AMD r9 390 would be an ideal system for Arma 3. Installing Arma 3 on an SSD would also lead to much faster loading times. Pros - Open world with eye dropping graphics- Realistic tactical Shooter- Amazing campaign that reliably produces stories- Large Varity of over 20 vehicles including tanks, cars, helicopters, aircraft and quads that can bedriven by players in the game- Selection of over 40 weapons to choose from that can be customised with their own types ofscopes and other various types of attachments- 15 types of stances that be very useful in exposing the least amount of your body to the enemy- Realistic weapon Ballistics- Servers can have up to 100 players in all out warfare- Community made content Cons -Highly PC system demanding-poorly optimised game engine

Posted: May 24, 2015
												This game has been great all the way through. You start the multiplayer completely lost in the number of controls, people running in the base and the helicopters flying overhead. It is a good thing the community if very understanding of this and helps new players get oriented all the time. Playing singleplayer is fun but the real stuff is in the multiplayer.   Once you get tired of the vanilla game  then go and try some mods. Play with six is a mod manager that works great for it. Most of the mods I have run into are highly detailed and work amazingly. It adds a completly new side to the game as it gives the option for players to get new gear, new weapons, new vehicles, new maps  and even new missions. All of which can be used on certain multiplayer servers. 10/10You will get your moneys worthCons- hackers (decent server admins deal with them often enough)- some tkers here and there but the majority of the community is good. - game bugs and servers go down (I feel it just acts as a signal I should finally take a break)- You cannot play for just an hour.  You will play for hours on end. (not something you can just pick up)

content:
Posted: December 31, 2015
												I've been a fan of ArmA ever since it was still known as Operation Flashpoint before the Bohemia Interactive and Codemasters dispute. (most people will now know it is ArmA: Cold War Assault but to me it'll always be Operation Flashpoint) I still have more hours in OpFlash than I probably ever will in any other ArmA game but this game is not disappointing.This game, however, isn't terribly innovative as far as gameplay, realism, or immersion. It's honestly just another rendition of my favorite series with slightly improved graphics, vastly improved physics, and only a few minor tweaks and streamlines to the flow of combat.ALTHOUGH that is not to say this game is bad by any means. ArmA has always had a "if it isn't broke, don't fix it" mentality and I actually appreciate that about Bohemia Interactive. They realize there's nothing wrong with the current formula for ArmA so they know better than to do stupid drastic changes that would more than likely destroy the series. It's a shame more companies don't do this.Great game from a great company that doesn't jump on some silly "easy to play easy to win" bandwagon. This is a difficult game that requires skill, micromanagement, strategic capabilities. This game is not recommended for people looking for instant gratification, easy gameplay, or being able to take more than a couple shots before they're down for the count.However if you like an extreme emphasis on teamwork, combined arms tactics, and community then this game is right up your alley and I recommend you buy it right now.
